Interjection

Question word ([q] - Adjective/Prep Phrase)

Verb(Adverb)

Subject(Subject - Adjective/Prep Phrase)...

Object(Object - Adjective/Prep Phrase)...

[Punctuation: STOP/Elipses/Repeat of punctuation at start for emphasis]



Note: to use a Verb as a noun (a gerund): Subject/Object Gerund (Verb)

Last Subject and Last Object refer to the most recent subject or object. The "Ordinal Tag" can be associated with any noun: Pronoun Subject or Object by prepending it followed by a number (usually limited to 1 2 3). Afterwards the Ordinal Tag and the number used can replace the noun until the number is associated with another noun.

Pronouns generally do not include gender but Masculine Feminine or Unknown can be added if relevant.

1st 2nd and 3rd person reference the singular (I you he/she). Adding Small/Medium/Large specifies plural (We You-all They). Small:2-5 Medium:6-25 Large: Followed by an approximate number generally 625 15625 140625 265625 2390625 4515625 4064062 76765625 690890625 or 1305015625

Possesive and Reflexive precede the pronoun.

Royal is followed by the correct Royal Character.

Desert: Empire Royal *like an Emperor or Empress
Tundra: Country Royal *like a President or Queen or Chairman
Mountain/Volcano: State Noble *like a Govenor or Duchess
Shrubland: District Noble *like a Countess or an Earl
Woodland: Borough Noble *like a Viscount or Baron
Forest: Estate Noble (with Castle) *like a Lord or Knight
Comment:
Names are:

TITLE:
ROLE:(Spouse / Advisor / Usurper / Commoner)
SCOPE: (Empire / Country / State / County / District Leader/ District / Estate Noble / Estate Head / City / Town / Village)
LOCALE: (Administrive Area at tat SCOPE)

Spouse's Character

Father's Character

Mother's Character's

FOLLOWED By the number corresponding to their Birth Order

And Finally their Family Name
Their Mother's Spouse Name
Their Father's Spouse Name

A baby has just their TITLE
column23:
one character for their birth order and their Family Name. At a year the mother adds a character before their brith order. At maturity the father adds a character before the mother's. During the wedding the spouse adds a character before the father's

City / Town / Village are at the same administrive level. Commoners use this level but it means Citizen / Merchant / Farmer and they use it only in formal settings. Nobles and Royals have Castles and Commoners living in a Castle use the Commoner character then that Noble's TITLE but it means Servant. Estates include associated farms and wild lands like forrests
column24:
lakes or mountains. Several Estates make a Borough. Several Boroughs make a District... make a County... make a State... make a Country... make an Empire

Uncrowned means next in line or current before the ceremony
BR>Usurper is bestowed by a Noble or Royal
column25: generally for treason but can be arbitrary and it can be revoked. In public the title must be used
column26:
but may be used alone

Spouse / Advisor may have their own line so the noble section repeats for that line
column27:
but only one line is carried over.

Most Spouses are commoners. Advisors are always royal or Noble.

Upon ascention of a new ruler: the ruler picks one character to precede the Spouse's chosen character
column28: Rulers may not be crowned if they are unmarried
column29: but they can have as many spouses as they want. Those not direct descendants of the ruler are stripped of their current SCOPE and become Estate Nobles. The new Ruler chooses the level below and may raise non descendants to that SCOPE even if they are commoners. The same occurs if one of his directs dies with no heirs.  This then occurs for each level in succession down to Borough Noble. They may pick new Estate Heads but cannot remove an Estate Noble. Estates and below are otherwise unaffected.

Swamp: Plagus*symptoms are similar but more deadly than the purple plague

Desert: oasis dolphin*small dolphins native to oasis
